Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Grand Valley State University Summer Undergraduate Research Program in Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program at Grand Valley State University will provide talented undergraduate students from across the nation with first-hand, experiential knowledge of the process of conducting mathematical research. Over the course of eight weeks each summer, eight undergraduate students will engage in mathematical research on an interesting, original, and mathematically significant topic selected by a faculty mentor. Research results may have applications in national security, political science, and industry. These experiences will enable participants to make an informed decision about pursuing a career as a mathematician.

During the program, faculty mentors will work to enhance students' written and verbal communication skills and build a community of scholars. Students are expected to present their findings several times over the summer. Projects funded by prior REUs at Grand Valley State University have resulted in prize-winning posters and numerous award-winning student talks at national meetings of mathematicians, and at least twenty published or accepted papers in peer-reviewed journals. Most of the alumni of the previous REUs choose to attend (or have attended) graduate school in mathematics or a closely related field. These students report that the REU had an impact on their choice to pursue a career in mathematics or a related field. The nonacademic career choices of program alumni include software engineering, working for the National Security Administration, and financial engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at Grand Valley State University in Allendale, MI during the summers of 2013, 2014, and 2015.

For eight weeks each summer, eight students from institutions across the United States worked in pairs with four faculty mentors, conducting original research on a variety of topics from pure and applied mathematics.  For example, a 2015 team of researchers proved that picture accompanying this article is an optimally dense packing of 3 equal circles on a surface called a flat Klein bottle. Of the 24 total participants, half (12) were male, and half (12) were female.

In addition to conducting research, participants also received training and mentoring to improve their oral and written communication skills.  All participants presented their work locally, at a statewide conference, and at MathFest, the national summer meetings of the Mathematical Association of America (MAA). (MathFest was held in Hartford, CT in 2013, Portland, OR in 2014, and Washington, DC in 2015.)  In addition, two students presented their work at the 2016 Joint Mathematics Meetings in Seattle, WA and one student presented his work at the 2015 Joint Mathematics Meetings in San Antonio, TX.

Participants won numerous awards for their presentations. At MathFest in 2013, one research group won an award from the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) for their talk on “Graph Theoretic Models of Interdependent Preferences in Referendum Elections”. At MathFest in 2014, two groups won an outstanding presentation award from the MAA: one for their talk on equal circle packing and another for their talk on gridline graphs. Finally, at MathFest in 2015, one groups won an awards from the MAA for their presentation on equal circle packing on flat Klein bottles.

In addition to presenting their work at local, state, and national conferences, many program participants have continued to work with their mentors after the conclusion of the summer program to prepare manuscripts for publication in peer-reviewed journals.  Many papers about the research have either been submitted or are in preparation.

While many of the 2013-2015 REU participants are still completing their undergraduate studies, others have gone on to enroll in graduate programs in mathematics or related fields.  Currently, alumni of the 2013 program are enrolled at Iowa State University, University of California-Berkeley, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, University of Colorado-Boulder, California State University-Sacramento, and University of Minnesota.  Alumni of the 2014 program are enrolled at Macalester College, Mills College, and one is a mathematics instructor at Johnson College Prep in Chicago.

In summary, the Summer Mathematics REU at Grand Valley State University provided 24 undergraduate students an opportunity to conduct original research in mathematics and to present their work in various local, state, and national venues.  These students won numerous awards for their research, and many have gone on to graduate school in mathematics and related fields.  The research from this REU has practical applications to problems such as designing voting systems.
